docs.title: Instructors

docs.text: 3. Lab Tasks 3.1. Day 1 tasks In Day 1 lab, you will change BR3 CSR1kv cEdge from vmanage mode to CLI mode. You will remove the pre-built device template for BR3-cEdge1. Then you will create new device template for BR3-cEdge1 based on the CLI configuration. You need to take screenshot after each task is completed, and submit your screenshot to the instructor. 3.1.1. Change br3-cedge1 to CLI mode Note : take a screenshot like the one below 3.1.2. Remove device template for br3-cedge1 Locate the pre-built device-template for br3-cedge1 and delete it. Note : take a screenshot like the one below 3.1.3. Build device template for br3-cedge1 Note :Name your Feature template and Device template starting with "CX" Hint: You need to create following feature template: System/NTP/BFD/Security/VPN0/VPN_Interface/VPN512/VPN1/VPN1_Interface Note : Take screenshot for all new feature template and device template 3.1.4. Attach br3-cedge1 to new device template Note : Before push config, run side by side diff to compare 3.1.5. combine two device template (optional) The pre-built configuration uses two different device templates for dc1-cedge1 and dc1-cedge2. Read the pre-built device template and see if you can change to single device template for both dc1-cedge1 and dc1-cedge2. Submit your screenshots from Day 1 task to box folder Note : the step by step video below should be only used for reference
docs.title: Day 1 Tasks

docs.text: In Day 1 lab, you will change BR3 CSR1kv cEdge from vmanage mode to CLI mode. You will remove the pre-built device template for BR3-cEdge1. Then you will create new device template for BR3-cEdge1 based on the CLI configuration. You need to take screenshot after each task is completed, and submit your screenshot to the instructor. 3.1.1. Change br3-cedge1 to CLI mode Note : take a screenshot like the one below 3.1.2. Remove device template for br3-cedge1 Locate the pre-built device-template for br3-cedge1 and delete it. Note : take a screenshot like the one below 3.1.3. Build device template for br3-cedge1 Note :Name your Feature template and Device template starting with "CX" Hint: You need to create following feature template: System/NTP/BFD/Security/VPN0/VPN_Interface/VPN512/VPN1/VPN1_Interface Note : Take screenshot for all new feature template and device template 3.1.4. Attach br3-cedge1 to new device template Note : Before push config, run side by side diff to compare 3.1.5. combine two device template (optional) The pre-built configuration uses two different device templates for dc1-cedge1 and dc1-cedge2. Read the pre-built device template and see if you can change to single device template for both dc1-cedge1 and dc1-cedge2.
docs.title: 3.1. Day 1 tasks

docs.text: Note : the step by step video below should be only used for reference
docs.title: Submit your screenshots from Day 1 task to box folder

docs.text: 3.2. Day 2 tasks In Day 2 lab, you will create local policy for QoS, OSPF route-policy and BGP route-policy. 3.2.1. OSPF local policy In this task, you will configure local route policy on DC1-SanJose and DC2-NewYork to prevent routing loop between OSPF and OMP redistribution. You need 1. Configure OSPF as service side routing protocol for dc2-cedge1/dc2-cedge2, and form OSPF neighbor with DC2-CSR router. 2. Configure local route-policy on dc2-cedge1/dc2-cedge2 to - tag 200 for routes being redistributed from OMP to OSPF. - block OSPF routes with tag 100 on service side from DCI router 3. Configure local route-policy on dc1-cedge1/dc1-cedge2 to - tag 100 for routes being redistributed from OMP to OSPF. - block OSPF routes with tag 200 on service side from DCI router Note : After applying local policy, save DC1-cedge1/DC1-cedge2/DC2-cedge1 running-config to files. Verify the routes are being tagged based on policy from CSR-DCI. CSR-1#show ip route tag 100 Routing entry for 10.30.100.0/24 Known via "ospf 100", distance 110, metric 16777214 Tag 100, type extern 2, forward metric 1 Last update from 10.10.100.1 on GigabitEthernet1, 00:26:18 ago Routing Descriptor Blocks: * 10.10.200.1, from 10.10.200.1, 00:26:18 ago, via GigabitEthernet2 Route metric is 16777214, traffic share count is 1 Route tag 100 10.10.100.2, from 19.1.1.12, 00:26:18 ago, via GigabitEthernet1 Route metric is 16777214, traffic share count is 1 Route tag 100 10.10.100.1, from 19.1.1.11, 00:26:18 ago, via GigabitEthernet1 Route metric is 16777214, traffic share count is 1 Route tag 100 Routing entry for 11.1.1.0/24 Known via "ospf 100", distance 110, metric 16777214 Tag 100, type extern 2, forward metric 1 Last update from 10.10.100.1 on GigabitEthernet1, 00:26:18 ago Routing Descriptor Blocks: * 10.10.200.1, from 10.10.200.1, 00:26:18 ago, via GigabitEthernet2 Route metric is 16777214, traffic share count is 1 Route tag 100 10.10.100.2, from 19.1.1.12, 00:26:18 ago, via GigabitEthernet1 Route metric is 16777214, traffic share count is 1 Route tag 100 10.10.100.1, from 19.1.1.11, 00:26:18 ago, via GigabitEthernet1 Route metric is 16777214, traffic share count is 1 Route tag 100 CSR-1#show ip route tag 200 Routing entry for 19.1.1.0/24 Known via "ospf 100", distance 110, metric 16777214 Tag 200, type extern 2, forward metric 1 Last update from 10.10.200.1 on GigabitEthernet2, 00:26:32 ago Routing Descriptor Blocks: * 10.10.200.1, from 10.10.200.1, 00:26:32 ago, via GigabitEthernet2 Route metric is 16777214, traffic share count is 1 Route tag 200 3.2.2. QoS policy Configure local policy to achieve following QoS requirements on BR3. Trust packets with DSCP 46 from LAN side and assign to VOICE class Trust packets with DSCP CS3 from LAN side and assign to CRITICAL class Mark telnet/ssh/snmp from LAN side to DSCP AF21 and assign to CRITICAL class Mark syslog from LAN side to DSCP af11 and assign to SCAVENGER class Mark everything else to DSCP 0 and assign to DEFAULT class Configure 4 queue model with VOICE, CRITICAL, SCAVENGER, DEFAULT classes Configure following queuing policy and apply on all transport interfaces. Class Bandwidth % drop Voice 30% tail CRITICAL 40% tail SCAVENGER 1% RED DEFAULT 29% RED Apply the QoS classification/Marking on BR3-cEdge1 LAN side interface; Apply QoS queueing policy on BR3-cEdge1 transport interfaces Note : After applying local policy, save BR3-cEdge1 running-config to a file. 3.2.3. change DC1 and DC2 service side routing protocl from OSPF to BGP (optional task) Submit your saved configuration files from Day 2 task to box folder Note : the step by step video below should be only used for reference Task 1 Task 2
docs.title: Day 2 Tasks

docs.text: 3.3. Day 3 tasks In Day 3 lab, you will configure central policy for route preference, arbitrary topology, and App-aware routing. Central policy 3.3.1. Configure central route policy * prefer local originated prefixes from DC1 (10.10.100.0/24) over DC1 TLOCs * prefer local originated prefixes from DC2 (10.10.200.0/24) over DC2 TLOCs. * DC2 will be used as backup path for DC1 prefix and DC1 will be used as backup path for DC2 prefix. 3.3.2. Configure central control policy * build hub-spoke topology with DC1/DC2 as the hub sites and BR3/BR4 as spokes. * block tunnels between DC1 and DC2 using central policy * (optional) Create additional VPN across all sites and make it full mesh topology 3.3.3. Configure Central App-Aware routing policy SLA Threshold Applications Prefer transport Voice Jitter:30msec Latency:300msec Loss:1% DSCP46 mpls primary , internet back up BE Jitter:500msec Latency:500msec Loss:3% All traffic ECMP Select Preview from you configured central policy, as show from below screenshot. Save the preview policy to a file. After you have created the central policy, try to active it. Are you able to active the policy? Try to fix the error so you can active the central policy. To verify App-aware routing, you can use the latency generator to introduce delay/jitter/drop. The latency generator is between mpls transport and br1-csr1 as show below. Try introduce some latency/jitter/drop and verify whether the app-aware routing works as expected. Submit your saved policy file from Day 3 task to box folder Note : the step by step video below should be only used for reference Task 1 Task 2 Task 3
docs.title: Day 3 Tasks

docs.text: In Day 3 lab, you will configure central policy for route preference, arbitrary topology, and App-aware routing.

docs.text: 3.3.1. Configure central route policy * prefer local originated prefixes from DC1 (10.10.100.0/24) over DC1 TLOCs * prefer local originated prefixes from DC2 (10.10.200.0/24) over DC2 TLOCs. * DC2 will be used as backup path for DC1 prefix and DC1 will be used as backup path for DC2 prefix. 3.3.2. Configure central control policy * build hub-spoke topology with DC1/DC2 as the hub sites and BR3/BR4 as spokes. * block tunnels between DC1 and DC2 using central policy * (optional) Create additional VPN across all sites and make it full mesh topology 3.3.3. Configure Central App-Aware routing policy SLA Threshold Applications Prefer transport Voice Jitter:30msec Latency:300msec Loss:1% DSCP46 mpls primary , internet back up BE Jitter:500msec Latency:500msec Loss:3% All traffic ECMP Select Preview from you configured central policy, as show from below screenshot. Save the preview policy to a file. After you have created the central policy, try to active it. Are you able to active the policy? Try to fix the error so you can active the central policy. To verify App-aware routing, you can use the latency generator to introduce delay/jitter/drop. The latency generator is between mpls transport and br1-csr1 as show below. Try introduce some latency/jitter/drop and verify whether the app-aware routing works as expected.
docs.title: Central policy

docs.title: Submit your saved policy file from Day 3 task to box folder

docs.text: 3.4. Day 4 tasks In Day 4 lab, you will enable DIA on BR3 and convert QoS local marking policy to Central QoS policy. 3.4.1. Direct Internet Access Configure DIA on BR3 to use local internet transport for internet-bound traffic. To demonstrate the result of DIA, please capture and compare the output of 'traceroute 19.1.7.10' from BR3_desk console. viptela@ubuntu:~$ traceroute 19.1.7.10 Note : save the before and after traceroute screenshots to a file 3.4.2. QoS Central policy To enforce QoS policy standardization across the fabric, change the local QoS marking policy configured in day 2 task to a centralized QoS policy and apply to all sites. Note : save the preview of updated central policy to a file. 3.4.3. Automation tool - Sastre Sastre is a Cisco internal developted automation tool for SD-WAN. Sastre is available in two flavors: Sastre : Public open-source under MIT license available on Cisco DevNet repository. Supports a limited set of tasks. Sastre-Pro : Cisco licensed version, supporting the full feature-set. Sastre-Pro is available for customers with a CX BCS subscription and internally at Cisco. Download and install Sastre-Pro ; backup all policies and templates from lab vManage to your local drive. 3.4.4. Upgrade Upgrade controllers to 19.2.3 and cEdges to 16.12.3 Submit your saved files from Day 4 task to box folder Note *: the step by step video below should be only used for reference
docs.title: Day 4 Tasks

docs.text: CX SD-WAN Bootcamp Lab Guide Introduction Welcome to CX SD-WAN bootcamp. This lab covers SD-WAN base and advanced knowledge including configuring feature template/device template, local routing policy, local data policy, central routing policy, control policy, app-aware routing policy and some common use cases like DIA, QoS etc. Unlike other bootcamp's lab guide, this lab guide doesn't include detail step by step instructions. Instead we give you the objective and intent for each task, you need to do your research and complete the task. Upon completion of the task, you need upload screenshots or configuration files to show the results to your instructor. 1. Lab Access 1.1. anyconnect to dCloud Connect to dCloud dcloud-rtp-anyconnect.cisco.com Note: found your login credential from login sheet 1.2. access POC tool url from Chrome https://198.18.133.200/virtual 1.3. login with username/password in table below username password dcloud@cisco.com C1sco12345 1.4. Verify lab topology Note: the lab topology has been pre-loaded for each pod. After login POC-tool console, you should see topology from 'Master View' - Login vManage to verify all controllers and WAN edges are up and running. https://198.18.133.200:8443 If controllers or WAN edge status does not match above screenshot, please try reboot vManage/vBond/vSmart from console. If that does not help, please ask your instructor to swap a new pod. 2. Lab Topology The lab is built with (NFV) network function virtualization. There is no physical appliance in the lab. To view the topology for each SDWAN site, login POC tool console and click the site name from the Topology View on the left. The connectivity and basic routing are pre-configured for the lab; here is the summary of the IP schema and information for each site. Site subnet SiteID Routing Protocol Control Plane 19.1.1.0/24 Static Internet Transport 19.0.0.0/8 Static MPLS Transport 10.0.0.0/8 Static DC1-SanJoe 10.10.100.0/24 100 OSPF,BGP ASN 100 DC2-NewYork 10.10.200.0/24 200 OSPF,BGP ASN 200 BR3-LosAngeles 10.30.100.0/24 30 Static BR4-RTP 10.40.100.0/24 40 VRRP
docs.title: Intro

docs.text: CX SD-WAN Bootcamp Lab Guide Introduction Welcome to CX SD-WAN bootcamp. This lab covers SD-WAN base and advanced knowledge including configuring feature template/device template, local routing policy, local data policy, central routing policy, control policy, app-aware routing policy and some common use cases like DIA, QoS etc. Unlike other bootcamp's lab guide, this lab guide doesn't include detail step by step instructions. Instead we give you the objective and intent for each task, you need to do your research and complete the task. Upon completion of the task, you need upload screenshots or configuration files to show the results to your instructor. 1. Lab Access 1.1. anyconnect to dCloud Connect to dCloud dcloud-rtp-anyconnect.cisco.com Note: found your login credential from login sheet 1.2. access POC tool url from Chrome https://198.18.133.200/virtual 1.3. login with username/password in table below username password dcloud@cisco.com C1sco12345 1.4. Import lab topology Note: the lab topology can be downloaded from box folder - Select v20.3.3 as VNF Version, and Next This will take 15 mins to load..... - After topology is loaded, Deploy Control Plane This will take 35 mins to load..... Once Control Plane is deployed, select each site and Deploy Click OK once all branches are deployed. 1.5. Verify lab topology Note: After all sites are successfully deployed, you should see topology from 'Master View' - Login vManage to verify all controllers and WAN edges are up and running. https://198.18.133.200:8443 2. Lab Topology The lab is built with (NFV) network function virtualization. There is no physical appliance in the lab. To view the topology for each SDWAN site, login POC tool console and click the site name from the Topology View on the left. The connectivity and basic routing are pre-configured for the lab; here is the summary of the IP schema and information for each site. Site subnet SiteID Routing Protocol Control Plane 19.1.1.0/24 Static Internet Transport 19.0.0.0/8 Static MPLS Transport 10.0.0.0/8 Static DC1-SanJoe 10.10.100.0/24 100 OSPF,BGP ASN 100 DC2-NewYork 10.10.200.0/24 200 OSPF,BGP ASN 200 BR3-LosAngeles 10.30.100.0/24 30 Static BR4-RTP 10.40.100.0/24 40 VRRP

docs.title: Survey
